title: The inside story on Bulgaria's night of shame: Sam Wallace reconstructs the disgraceful events that marred England's victory in Sofia
text:
The question that the England players are asked first in the aftermath of Monday night’s game at the Vasil Levski National stadium in Sofia is the easiest to answer: they first heard the racial abuse in the moments after they jogged out into the half-full ground for the warm-up.

The stadium is a 1950s Communist-era building: in the lobby some old shirts and a picture of the legendary 1994 Bulgaria team that went all the way to a World Cup semi-final and then inside, around the stands, the kind of fences penning in spectators long since discarded in English grounds. When the England players arrive on Monday night the Bulgarian Football Union has laid out a red carpet and ropes around the entrance hall that leads into the main stand.

Bulgarian football, the team itself, is on its knees. By Tuesday night they have lost 10 games in succession. The boys of 1994 are in their 50s now and they run the show, although not very successfully. Borislav Mikhailov, the goalkeeper from that team, most famous for playing in a wig so distinct it deserved its own squad number, is the president. Krasimir Balakov, a brilliant attacking midfielder from the 1994 team, is the manager. Both have pinned all the team’s Euro 2020 hopes on winning their Nations League qualifier. The qualifiers have been sacrificed and performances have been dreadful. Patience is running thin.
